svg.text: This version of the CT Sticky Masses simulation uses the GR domain to render the results
This example requires Java3D. If you do not have it installed, you can get it from: http://java.sun.com/products/java-media/3D/
Right click to look inside the states to see the model of the system behavior in the corresponding mode of operation.

The sticky masses system has two modes of operation, "Separate" and "Together," corresponding to whether the point masses are stuck together. The "init" state has a transition that is used to initialize the "Separate" model (double click on that transition to see its actions).

property.name: actions
property.value: Separate.p1 = p1; Separate.p2 = p2; Separate.v1 = v1; Separate.v2 = v2

property.name: setActions
property.value: Separate.p1 = P1; Separate.p2 = P1; Separate.v1 = V1; Separate.v2 = V1

svg.text: This model gives two separate ordinary differential equations, one for each point mass attached to a spring. The ZeroCrossingDetector actor detects the collision of the point masses and emits the "touched" event.
V1 and V2 are velocities, and P1 and P2 are positions of the two masses.
V1 and V2 are velocities, and P1 and P2 are positions of the two masses.
This model gives one ordinary differential equation for the joined point masses attached to a spring. A second differential equation models the decaying stickiness.
